message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about solubility. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar and salt, dissolve in water when combined. This is because the water molecules are able to surround and separate the individual carbohydrate molecules, allowing them to disperse evenly throughout the water. Iron (B), oil (C), and plastic (D) do not easily dissolve in water. Iron may rust when exposed to water, but it does not dissolve. Oil and plastic are hydrophobic, meaning they do not mix well with water and do not dissolve in it.

This question requires basic knowledge about solubility and the properties of different substances. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar, are soluble in water. When combined with water, sugar molecules interact with the water molecules, which causes the sugar to dissolve and form a homogenous solution. Iron, oil, and plastic, on the other hand, are not soluble in water. Iron is a metal and does not have the necessary properties to dissolve in water. Oil is non-polar and hydrophobic, meaning it does not mix well with water. Plastic is also non-polar and does not have the necessary properties to dissolve in water.

This question requires knowledge about the solubility of different substances in water. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar, are soluble in water. When they are combined with water, they dissolve and form a homogeneous solution. Iron, option (B), does not dissolve in water but may rust when exposed to it. Oil, option (C), is hydrophobic and does not dissolve in water. Plastic, option (D), is also not soluble in water. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) crystal carbohydrates.

This question requires knowledge of solubility. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugars and some types of salts, dissolve in water when combined. This is due to the polar nature of water molecules, which allows them to interact with and surround the ions or molecules of the crystal carbohydrate, breaking them apart and dispersing them throughout the water. Option (B) is incorrect because iron does not readily dissolve in water, although it can rust when exposed to water and oxygen. Option (C) is incorrect because oil and water do not mix, and oil does not dissolve in water. Option (D) is incorrect because plastic is a nonpolar substance and does not dissolve in water.

This question requires knowledge of solubility and the properties of different substances. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar, are soluble in water. When combined with water, the crystal carbohydrates break down into individual sugar molecules, which can disperse throughout the water. Iron, option (B), does not dissolve in water and instead may rust or react with water. Oil, option (C), is immiscible with water and forms a separate layer. Plastic, option (D), does not dissolve in water either.

This question requires knowledge about the solubility of different substances in water. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar or salt, are soluble in water and dissolve when combined. Iron is not soluble in water and does not dissolve when combined. Oil and plastic are both nonpolar substances and are not soluble in water.

This question requires knowledge about the solubility of different substances in water. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar and salt, dissolve in water when combined. This is because water molecules are polar, meaning they have positive and negative charges. This polarity allows water to attract and surround the individual ions or molecules of the carbohydrate, causing it to dissolve. Iron, oil, and plastic do not dissolve in water. Iron is a metal and is insoluble in water. Oil is nonpolar and does not mix with water, causing it to separate and float on top. Plastic is also nonpolar and does not dissolve in water.

Option (B) is incorrect because iron does not dissolve in water. Option (C) is incorrect because oil and water do not mix and oil does not dissolve in water. Option (D) is incorrect because plastic is generally insoluble in water.

Iron, option (B), is not soluble in water and will not dissolve. Oil, option (C), is also not soluble in water and will separate from it. Plastic, option (D), is not a substance that typically dissolves in water.

Option (B) is incorrect because iron does not dissolve in water. Option (C) is incorrect because oil is not soluble in water; in fact, oil and water do not mix. Crystal carbohydrates, such as sugar, have polar groups that can form hydrogen bonds with water molecules, making them soluble in water. Iron, oil, and plastic are not soluble in water. Option (B) is incorrect because iron is a metal and does not dissolve in water. Option (C) is incorrect because oil is nonpolar and does not form hydrogen bonds with water. This is because crystal carbohydrates have polar molecules, which means they have positive and negative ends. Water is a polar molecule and is able to break apart the crystal structure of carbohydrates, allowing the molecules to mix and dissolve in the water. Options (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they do not dissolve in water. Iron is a metal and does not have polar molecules to interact with water. Oil is nonpolar and does not mix with water, causing it to float on top. Plastic is also nonpolar and does not dissolve in water.

This question requires knowledge about the solubility of different substances in water. Crystal carbohydrates, such as table sugar or salt, dissolve in water when combined. This is because the polar water molecules surround and separate the individual ions or molecules of the crystal, allowing them to mix uniformly with the water. Option (B), iron, does not dissolve in water but can rust when exposed to it. Option (C), oil, does not dissolve in water because oil is nonpolar, while water is polar. Option (D), plastic, does not dissolve in water because most plastics are nonpolar and do not have an affinity for water molecules.

Iron is a metal and does not dissolve in water. Oil is nonpolar and does not mix with water, so it does not dissolve. Plastic, which is a polymer, does not dissolve in water either.
